passage:
Passage 1
	Low wages, chronic unemployment and underemployment lead to low income, lack of property ownership, absence of savings, absence of food reserves in the home, and a chronic shortage of cash. These conditions reduce the possibility of effective participation in the larger economic system. And as a response to these conditions we find in the culture QS$$1 of poverty a high incidence of pawning personal QE$$1 goods, borrowing from local moneylenders at usurious rates of interest, spontaneous informal credit devices organized by neighbors, the use of secondhand clothing and furniture, and the pattern of frequent buying of small quantities of food many times a day as the need arises.
	People with a culture of poverty produce very little wealth and receive very little in return. They have a low level of literacy and education, usually do not belong to labor unions, are not members of political parties, generally do not participate in the national welfare agencies, and make very little use of banks, hospitals, department stores, museums or art galleries. They have a critical attitude toward some of the basic institutions of the dominant classes, hatred of the police, mistrust of government and those in high position, and a cynicism which extends even to the church. This QS$$2 gives the culture of poverty a high potential for protest and for being used in political movements aimed against the existing social order.
	People with a QE$$2 culture of poverty are aware of middle-class values, talk about them and even claim some of them as their own, but on the whole they QS$$3 do not live by them. Thus it is important to distinguish between what they say and what they do. For example, many will tell you that QE$$3 marriage by law, by the church, or by both is the ideal form of marriage, but few
	will marry. To men who have no steady jobs or other sources of income, who do not own property and have no wealth to pass on to their children, who are present-time oriented and who want to avoid the expense and legal difficulties involved in formal marriage and divorce, free unions or consensual marriages make a lot of sense. Women will often turn down offers of marriage because they feel it ties them down to men who are immature, punishing and generally unreliable. Women feel that consensual union gives them a better break; it gives them some of the freedom and flexibility that men have. By not giving the fathers of their children legal status as husbands, the women have a stronger claim on their children if they decide to leave their men.
	It [consensual union] also gives women exclusive rights to a house or any other property they may own.
	 Passage 2
	You ask me what is poverty? Listen to me.
	Here I am, dirty, smelly, and with no “proper” underwear on and with the stench of my rotting teeth near you. I will tell you. Listen to me. Listen without pity. I cannot use your pity.
	Listen with understanding. Put yourself in my dirty, worn-out ill-fitting shoes, and hear me.
	Poverty is getting up every morning from a dirt- and illness-stained mattress. The sheets have long since been used for diapers. Poverty is living in a smell that never leaves. This is a smell of urine, sour milk, and spoiling food sometimes joined with the strong smell of long-cooked onions. Onions are cheap. If you have smelled this smell, you did not know how it came. It is the smell of the outdoor privy. It is the smell of young children who cannot walk the long dark way in the night. It is the smell of the mattresses where years of “accidents” have happened. It is the smell of the milk which has gone sour because the refrigerator long has not worked, and it costs money to get it fixed. It is the smell of rotting garbage. I could bury it, but where is the shovel? Shovels cost money.
	Poverty is always being tired. I have always been tired. They told me at the hospital when the last baby came that I had chronic anemia caused from poor diet, a bad case of worms, and that I needed a corrective opera tion. I listened politely—the poor are always polite. The poor QS$$8 always listen. They don’t say that there QE$$8 is no money for iron pills, or better food, or worm medicine. The idea of an operation is frightening and costs so much that, if I had dared, I would have laughed....
	Poverty is looking into a black future.
	Your children won’t play with my boys. They will turn to other boys who steal to get what they want. I can already see them behind the bars of their prison instead of QS$$5 behind the bars of my poverty. Or they will QE$$5 QS$$5 turn to the freedom of alcohol or drugs, and QE$$5 find themselves enslaved. And my daughter? At best, there is for her a life like mine.... Poverty is an acid that drips on pride until all pride is worn away.
	Poverty is a chisel that chips on honor until honor is worn away. Some of you say that you would do something in my situation, and maybe you would, for the first week or the first month, but for year after year after year? I have come out of my despair to tell you this. Remember I did not come from another place or another time. Others like me are all around you. Look at us with an angry heart, anger that will help you help me. Anger that will let you tell of me. The poor are always QS$$8 silent. Can you be silent too? QE$$8 QS$$8 QE$$8
header: The following passages discuss the problems of being poor in America. The first is an excerpt from a best-selling study of a Puerto Rican family, written by an anthropologist in the 1960s. The second is an excerpt from a speech given at a Florida school in 1965.

questions.description: A defining characteristic of poverty, according to the author of  Passage 1, is that poor people

options.description: lack the imagination to lift themselves outof poverty
lack the skills to find decent jobs
are constantly in a state of crisis
are somewhat responsible for their ownpoverty
are isolated from the mainstream of society

questions.description: The author of  Passage 1 uses the phrase “culture of poverty” (line 9) to suggest that

options.description: causes of poverty have been carefully studied and analyzed
poor people often take pride in their poverty
for some people poverty has become a prevailingway of life
poor people share a common background
there are several levels and classifications

questions.description: By asserting that the culture of poverty can be used by political movements (lines 30-33), the author is

options.description: predicting an uprising by the poor
citing a reason for eliminating poverty
cautioning the middle class to beware ofthe poor
criticizing the motives of politicians
alluding to a particular historical event

questions.description: The author’s point about the need to “distinguish between what they [poor people] say and what they do” (lines 37-39) is meant to suggest that

options.description: poor people are often hypocritical
lying is part of the culture of poverty
the poor are often unable to change theconditions of their lives
the poor are fooling themselves
poverty causes people to have illusions

questions.description: A conclusion to be drawn from the discussion of marriage in  Passage 1 is that men and women in the culture of poverty

options.description: avoid legalized marriages for practical andeconomic reasons
prefer to be independent
cannot afford to marry and raise a family
do not trust each other to be faithful husbandsand wives
consider themselves unworthy of legal

questions.description: The comparison between the “bars of their prison” and the “bars of my poverty” (lines 102 and 103) is meant to suggest that the speaker believes that

options.description: her sons must choose between a life ofcrime and a life of poverty
escaping from poverty is more difficultthan escaping from prison
her sons can escape from poverty but notfrom prison
crime results from poverty
poverty and imprisonment are similar

questions.description: Evidence in  Passage 2 suggests that the  speaker lives

options.description: on an isolated farm
in an urban slum
in a housing project
in the country
near a big city

questions.description: The primary emotion conveyed by the speaker in  Passage 2 is

options.description: jealousy
resentment
discouragement
hopelessness
resignation

questions.description: When the speaker says “the poor always listen” (line 93) and “the poor are always silent” (lines 118 and 119) she is implying that poor people

options.description: feel intimidated by authority
cannot express themselves articulately
prefer to keep to themselves
suffer from powerlessness
don’t want to antagonize other people

questions.description: The main intent of the speaker in  Passage 2 is to

options.description: convey information about poverty to theaudience
enrage the audience
arouse the audience to action
define poverty
describe real differences between the rich

questions.description: Compared to  Passage 1,  Passage 2 is more likely to evoke an emotional response from the reader because

options.description: it uses shocking language
it is written in first person singular
the speaker shows intense emotion
it repeatedly uses the word poverty
the audience is addressed as “you”

questions.description: In discussing poverty, the authors of both passages seem to agree that poverty

options.description: cannot be clearly defined
means more than lack of money
is more widespread than most people think
cannot be eliminated
weakens the fabric of society

questions.description: Passage 2 illustrates the contention in  Passage 1 that the poor

options.description: suffer from a chronic shortage of cash
mistrust the government
have a low level of literacy and education
rely on neighbors to borrow money
make little use of banks, hospitals, and
